docs.title: mkdocs-eds demo
docs.text: This mini site demonstrates the plugins of mkdocs-eds. Each page in the Extensions section highlights a specific feature with a small snippet you can copy into your own docs.

docs.title: Add mkdocs-eds to your project
docs.text:
Add mkdocs-eds to your Python environment (ideally in a dev group): 

uv add git+https://github.com/aphp/mkdocs-eds.git --group dev

docs.title: Run the demo locally
docs.text:
Clone the project and install it: 

uv sync

Build or serve the docs: 

mkdocs serve

The demo uses the small package in demo_package as input for the auto-generated reference pages.

docs.title: Auto-generated reference
docs.text:
The auto_gen_pages plugin scans one or more package roots and creates virtual Markdown pages for every module it finds. The generated pages are routed into your navigation so you never have to maintain a manual reference section.

Key behaviors in this demo:

  • The Reference: reference/ entry in mkdocs.yml is replaced with a nested tree that mirrors the demo_package layout.
  • Each module gets a demo_package.module directive using the custom mkdocstrings templates shipped with mkdocs-eds.
  • Section index pages gain a visible Overview link so the directory itself is clearly clickable.
plugins:
  - auto_gen_pages:
      package_dirs:
        - demo_package
      reference_section: Reference

Add or remove modules under demo_package and the reference updates automatically on the next build.

docs.title: Cards layout
docs.text: Use the cards plugin to drop lightweight card layouts straight into Markdown. Start a card with === card, then write normal Markdown inside each block. Add href attributes to make the whole card clickable.

docs.title: Faster onboarding
docs.text: Link out to a single page that collects the must-read guides for newcomers.

docs.title: Clickable code →
docs.text: Code blocks can link back into your reference pages automatically.

docs.title: Live snippets
docs.text: Render live Pret components side by side with their source.

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
Add this to your markdown file:

=== card

    #### Faster onboarding

    Link out to a single page that collects the must-read guides for newcomers.

=== card {: href="/extensions/clickable-code/" }

    #### Clickable code →

    Code blocks can link back into your reference pages automatically.

=== card {: href="/extensions/pret-snippets/" }

    #### Live snippets

    Render live Pret components side by side with their source.

and make sure to enable the cards plugin in your mkdocs.yml:

plugins:
  ...
  - cards
  ...

docs.title: Citations
docs.text: The bibtex plugin understands Pandoc-style citations and builds a references section for any cited works. Entries come from docs/references.bib, and you can also declare ad-hoc references inside a page.

docs.title: Demo
docs.text:
The material theme is used throughout these docs Squidfunk, 2024 and Pret is used for the interactive example Wajsburt, 2024. Citations can be combined or re-used multiple times without repeating the bibliography entry.

Need to cite something not in the BibTeX file? Define it inline like [@demo-ref] above and it will show up in the references list.

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
For instance in this page:

Some text that cites mkdocs [@mkdocs-material] and mkdocs-eds [@demo-ref].

[@demo-ref]: Wajsburt, 2024. Documentation prototypes with mkdocs-eds.

Some more text.

Make sure to enable the bibtex plugin in your mkdocs.yml:

plugins:
    ...
    - bibtex:
        bib_file: references.bib
    ...

  1. Squidfunk., 2024. Material for MkDocs. https://squidfunk.github.io/mkdocs-material/

  2. Wajsburt P., 2024. Pret. https://github.com/percevalw/pret

  3. Wajsburt, 2024. Documentation prototypes with mkdocs-eds.

docs.title: Clickable code
docs.text:
The clickable_code plugin links identifiers inside fenced code blocks to their documentation and adds [source] links next to headings whose IDs look like Python import paths.

  • Identifiers in multi-line <code> blocks resolve through mkdocs-autorefs, so the import path must match something in the reference section.
  • Absolute links like /reference/demo_package/ are rewritten relative to the current page.
  • Set repo_url in mkdocs.yml (autodetected from git remote if omitted) to generate source links.

docs.title: Demo
docs.text:
from demo_package.math import MovingAverage, scale_values

avg = MovingAverage(window=4)
data = scale_values([1, 2, 3, 4], factor=1.5)
for value in data:
    avg.update(value)
Some padding div to demonstrate what happens when you click on the `MovingAverage` identifier above.

docs.title: Redirection for MovingAverage
docs.text: This heading receives a [source] link that points at the exact line inside the demo package on GitHub. Additionally, any occurrence of MovingAverage inside code blocks will link here.

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
Add any code block like this to your markdown file:

```python
from demo_package.math import MovingAverage, scale_values

avg = MovingAverage(window=4)
data = scale_values([1, 2, 3, 4], factor=1
for value in data:
    avg.update(value)
```

#### Redirection for MovingAverage {: #demo_package.math.MovingAverage }

This heading receives a `[source]` link that points at the exact line inside the
demo package on GitHub. Additionally, any occurrence of `MovingAverage` inside code blocks will
link here. You can put this anywhere in your docs, not necessarily next to the code block.

and enable the clickable_code plugin in your mkdocs.yml. Set the repo_url to to your project repository to generate source links. To ensure that overrides (like the {: #demo_package.math.MovingAverage } above) are the one that take precedence when the user clicks on an identifier, set the priority option of autorefs to have reference after *.

plugins:
    ...
    - autorefs:
      priority:
        - "*"
        - reference
    - clickable_code
      repo_url: https://github.com/aphp/mkdocs-eds
    ...

docs.title: Pret snippet renderer
docs.text: Run Python code blocks and render their results inline using Pret. Add the render-with-pret class to a fenced Python block to execute it at build time and embed the returned component right below the code. The optional code--expandable class wraps the code in a collapsible <details> block.

docs.title: Demo
docs.text:
Show code 
from pret_joy import Button, Typography, Stack

Button("Click me!", sx={"m": 1})

docs.title: Code
docs.text:
Make sure the pret package is installed in your environment before building the site so the renderer can bundle the assets.

Add this to your markdown file:

your-page.md
```python { .render-with-pret .code--expandable }
from pret_joy import Button, Typography, Stack

Button("Click me!", sx={"m": 1})
```

and enable the pret_snippet_renderer plugin in your mkdocs.yml:

mkdocs.yml
plugins:
    ...
    - pret_snippet_renderer
    ...

docs.text: Demo package used to showcase the mkdocs-eds extensions.

docs.title: MovingAverage
docs.text: Compute a moving average over the most recent values.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
PARAMETER DESCRIPTION window

Number of samples used to compute the average. Must be positive.

TYPE: int DEFAULT: 3

docs.title: update
docs.text: Add a value to the window and return the current average.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
PARAMETER DESCRIPTION value

New data point.

TYPE: float

RETURNS DESCRIPTION float

The average of the recorded values.

docs.title: as_dict
docs.text:
Serialize the current state.

RETURNS DESCRIPTION dict[str, float]

Dictionary with the window size and the number of values seen.

docs.title: add
docs.text: Add two numbers.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
PARAMETER DESCRIPTION a

First value.

TYPE: float

b

Second value.

TYPE: float

RETURNS DESCRIPTION float

The sum of both numbers.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: add(1, 2)

docs.title: scale_values
docs.text: Scale every value by a factor.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
PARAMETER DESCRIPTION values

Iterable of numbers to scale.

TYPE: Iterable[float]

factor

Multiplier applied to each value.

TYPE: float DEFAULT: 1.0

RETURNS DESCRIPTION list[float]

Scaled values as a list.

RAISES DESCRIPTION ValueError

If the factor is zero.
